moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 d5 4. Nf3 c6 5: All the games start from this position, with White to move. I had never done a Nimzo-Indian theme before this tournament,  but know it's a very popular defense.
moves.9. O-O Bb4 10. e4: Now that I've castled, I can initiate complications.
moves.10... O-O: My opponent, likewise, castles before plunging towards the middle game.
moves.11. e5: A Knight on KB3, according to Fine and Znosko-Borovsky, is the best single piece available to protect a King that has castled King-side. So naturally, I drive it away while I have the opportunity.
moves.11... Ne8: The best available square. N-R4 would leave it exposed and vulnerable.
moves.12... f6: An attempt to negate my central wedge.
moves.13... Ba5: A move seemingly without a purpose. According to Fine, it is better to have a bad plan than not to have a plan at all. Every move should have some purpose.
moves.14. Bxh7+: I naturally take the free Pawn, a move that also exposes Black's King somewhat.
moves.14... Kh8: K-B2 would leave the King closer to his allies, although I'm not sure it would have made a huge difference.
moves.15. Qg6: Naturally, I press forward with the Q. My Knight is also ready to join, and the Black King is momentarily denuded of defensive help.
moves.15... fxe5: An attempt to reduce the pressure.
moves.16... Qf6: Black's previous move cleared this square. Needless to say, I have no intention of exchanging Queens!
moves.17... e4: The correct move was 17... Q-R3, interrupting the potential discovery. Now I have a mate.
